You have a hand of $n$ cards, each with a number on it. You can perform the following operation any number of times:

* Choose $k$ cards from your hand that all have the same number.
* Exchange these $k$ cards for $k-1$ new cards, where each new card can have any number.

What is the minimum number of cards you can have left in your hand after any number of these operations?

Input:

* The first line contains $t$ (the number of test cases).
* For each test case:
    * The first line contains two integers $n$ and $k$ ($1 \le n \le 100$, $2 \le k \le 100$).
    * The next line contains $n$ integers $c_1, c_2, ..., c_n$ ($1 \le c_i \le 100$).

Output:

* For each test case, output a single integer - the minimum number of cards you can have left.
You have a set of numbered items. You can trade a group of $k$ identical items for $k-1$ new items of your choosing. What is the fewest items you can have left?
